properties.DESCRIPTION: The north end of Watts Island supported a dense mature forest in the 1980s. This end of the island eroded and is now permanently inundated shallow shoal.
The south end of Watts Island  had a mature and dense forest in the 1980s, but the area has now eroded to a permanently inundated shallow shoal.

Up until the 1980's, Goose Island was covered with saltbush and cedars. The vegetation has since succumb to saltwater intrusion and the island is now just a shallow shoal that is permanently inundated.
A cabin called "Winter Quarters" which belonged to the Scarborough family, was used here for 200 years. The cabin is now gone, and the island is no bigger than a large table.
There was a 75 foot-long tump of trees on Finney's Island until the 1980s. The hummock had completely disappeared due to saltwater intrusion by 2013.
In the 1970s a gap of about 6-10 feet opened on Finney's Island, just wide enough to get a boat through. The gap has since grown to more than 300 feet wide.
In the 1980s, this tump of trees was used by hunters to hide their boat before walking over to the second tump on Finney's Island. Both tumps of trees are now gone due to saltwater intrusion.
Finney's Island had a nice hook and tip on its north end which are now permanently under water.
Little Fox Island is now completely inundated. It recently came up for a tax sale and someone bought it not knowing the island was no longer above water.
This pond is consistently enlarging with the rising water levels.
Hurricane Sandy took out a gun club's cabin here in 2012. The entire point eroded away.
The Back Creek Tump at the mouth of Back Creek and Beasley Bay  disappeared over a 15 year span between 1985 and 2000.

In order to hold back rising water levels, dikes were constructed along the woods here in the early 20th century in order to protect the area so that strawberries could be grown. The dikes now define the marsh, and the woods are dying back.

There is a manmade canal with a cordouroy road next to it here. The road is now under water by a half meter at mid-tide. The nearby Hopkins Village store was abandoned sometime in the twentieth century.
At the mouth of Cattail Creek, there was a tump with trees that is now gone

In the 19th century, Bird Island wa farmed.  The farmer drove oxen out to it at low tide on a shoal. A hurricane cut a gut so that he could no longer drive across. Now there is almost nothing left but two small pieces separated by an expanse of water.
Bird Island was previously a prime Black Duck breeding ground due to the lack of predators.  It is not more than a shoal now, and Black Ducks have moved inland to nest.
The whole southern tip of Cedar Island has been washed away since 2012. Several houses were standing in water before their owners burned them.

Up until the 1950s, this small bar held a duck blind, and there were tree stumps in the water south towards Watts Island. In the 1860 Census, three or four families lived on Fox Island. There is nothing left of the bar with the duck blind.
The north end of the Matthews House was washed away. The family then moved into the Oyster House next to the cove on the north side of the town.
There was a whole line of houses on the western side of town that are now gone. The sites they occupied are now under water.
The pond next to the road has enlarged by three times in the past five years.
A number of graveyards on Watts Island attests to the many people who lived there.
The shoreline in Saxis has eroded back 200 to 300 feet probably due to erosion from storms.
The shoreline in Saxis has eroded back 200 to 300 feet probably due to erosion from storms.
Since 1967, a saltwater pond has formed behind the dune ridges on Fisherman's Island.
Dead cedar stumps in the water along this area show where the water level was previously.
Gin and Juice Island was formerly near the mouth of Nassawadox Creek. It has disappeared and now exists as a shallow shoal.

Sand Point disappeared. Rip rap from shore stabilization north of here has starved the point of sand and expedited impacts from sea-level rise. This upland area was so wide and forested that people could camp on either side of the point and not know anyone else was there.
Honeymoon Island was situated at the mouth of Mattawoman Creek. This island is now permanently inundated and it exists as a shoal that is now used for clam aquaculture.
Tree stumps once lined the shoreline here but have since disappeared. Beach Island used to have very high dunes,  but is now shrinking and flatter.

Two small islands eroded and  the sand shoals eventually built up Beach Island.  Once it moved onto shore, people could no longer go up that creek. It was called Dynamite Gut (because you'd dynamite to blast a channel through it).
Tidal marsh has dissappeared in this area.
Tidal marsh has dissappeared in this area.

Long sand point Pole's (Powells on map) Bluff, has disappeared. There is no shoreline stabilization north of here  to rob sand from the creek mouth.  It was a big sand dune and a useful landmark when on the water. There is now a small upland area at southeast edge of where it stood.
The beach in central Assawoman Island has been rolling over and filling the water bodies on the west side of the island.
Long Point has shrunk by 30 or 40 yards since the 1990s.
